factoid: Sónya had a glad consciousness that she had not undressed during the first three nights.
Sónya was ready to carry out all the doctor's injunctions with precision.
Sónya kept awake at night so as not to miss the proper time when the slightly harmful pills in the little gilt box had to be administered.
Natásha found it pleasant to see that many sacrifices were being made for her.
Natásha found it pleasant to know that she had to take medicine at certain hours.
Natásha declared that no medicine would cure her.
Natásha declared that medicine was nonsense.
Natásha demonstrated that she did not believe in medical treatment by disregarding orders.
Natásha demonstrated that she did not value her life by disregarding orders.
The doctor came every day to see Natásha.
The doctor felt Natásha's pulse.
The doctor looked at Natásha's tongue.
The doctor joked with Natásha regardless of her grief-stricken face.
The doctor assumed a grave air after going into another room.
The doctor shook his head thoughtfully and said that though there was danger, he had hopes of the effect of the last medicine.
The doctor said one must wait and see.
The doctor said the malady was chiefly mental.
The countess hurriedly followed the doctor into another room.
The countess tried to conceal the action from herself and from the doctor.
The countess slipped a gold coin into the doctor's hand.
The countess always returned to the patient with a more tranquil mind.
Natásha ate little.
Natásha slept little.
Natásha coughed.
Natásha was always low-spirited.
The doctors said Natásha could not get on without medical treatment.
The doctors kept Natásha in the stifling atmosphere of the town.
The Rostóvs did not move to the country that summer of 1812.
Natásha swallowed many pills.
Natásha swallowed drops and powders from little bottles and boxes.
Madame Schoss was fond of such things and made a large collection.
Natásha was deprived of the country life to which she was accustomed.
Youth prevailed for Natásha.
Natásha’s grief began to be overlaid by impressions of daily life.
Natásha’s grief ceased to press so painfully on her heart.
Natásha’s grief gradually faded into the past.
Natásha began to recover physically.
Natásha was calmer.
Natásha was not happier.
Natásha avoided all external forms of pleasure such as balls, promenades, concerts, and theaters.
Natásha never laughed without a sound of tears in her laughter.
Natásha could not sing.
As soon as Natásha began to laugh, tears choked her.
Tears choked Natásha were tears of remorse.
Tears choked Natásha were tears at the recollection of those pure times which could never return.
Tears choked Natásha were tears of vexation that she should have ruined her young life which might have been happy.
Laughter seemed to Natásha like a blasphemy in face of her sorrow.
Singing seemed to Natásha like a blasphemy in face of her sorrow.
Natásha had no need of self-restraint.
Natásha had no wish to coquet.
No wish to coquet entered Natásha's head.
Natásha said that no man was more to her than Nastásya Ivánovna, the buffoon.
Something stood sentinel within Natásha and forbade her every joy.
Natásha had lost all the old interests of her carefree girlish life that had been full of hope.
Natásha recalled the previous autumn hunting, “Uncle,” and the Christmas holidays spent with Nicholas at Otrádnoe often and painfully.
Natásha would not have given up to bring back even a single day of that time.
That time was gone forever.
Natásha's presentiment at the time had not deceived her.
That state of freedom and readiness for any enjoyment would not return again.
It was necessary for Natásha to live on.
